Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: A STEM toolkit enabling global air quality experiments
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase I project seeks to address the primary pain point for experiential learning of environmental science: it is nearly impossible to conduct engaging experiments on a limited local basis. The ability to collaborate regionally or globally will enable students to participate in meaningful exploration of the impact of natural and human-based events on air quality. This project teaches environmental science in a way that engages students with real-world problems and allows them to harness their own creativity. These methods have been shown to be especially effective for encouraging young women to pursue science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) educational programs and careers. This is particularly important as both minorities and women are highly underrepresented in these fields. Through successful commercialization and integration of this project?s resulting technology with high school and post-secondary curricula, educators will increase the likelihood of their students to pursue STEM careers. Encouraging further education in these fields, particularly for underrepresented groups, will lead to a more diversified work force promoting greater productivity and advancement of scientific discovery.

This project is innovative in the field of Educational Technology, which has yet to adopt web-connected sensors that generate big data on a global scale. This is primarily due to the fact that current technology is prone to inaccuracy and failure, and is often difficult to use. The proposed project will lead to the creation of educational software, a complement existing hardware, to make the product system fun and easy to install and use. The app will facilitate data-sharing in a global network and include: GIS mapping, continuous logging, time averaging, annotation, and integration with compatible software systems. This project seeks to achieve three key objects. First, a user-friendly tool will be built to view and analyze data. This will be assessed using feedback from a focus group. Second, a curriculum will be constructed through educator-researcher collaboration to ensure educational usefulness for both educators and their students. Lastly, usability and feasibility will be tested through prototype development. For this objective students will be recruited to interact with the prototype and evaluate the user-friendliness of the app and effectiveness of the curriculum. The success of the proposed project includes demonstration of usability, feasibly and educational effectiveness of the developed software.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Under this grant, Wicked Device continued development of an innovative software platform that will be paired with the company’s existing Air Quality Egg, which is an affordable, networked, environmental sensor that engages secondary students in learning environmental science. Given the student interest in global warming and the complex, interdisciplinary, real-world nature of environmental science, it is an excellent vehicle for STEM learning. Wicked Device’s Air Quality Egg and software solution will be marketed to secondary and post-secondary instructors who want to engage their students in a global network of web-connected sensors that collect data and post to the internet. This will be the first solution to enable engaging, coordinated, multi-school experiments on a global level.

During the period of performance, we were able to develop the infrastructure and software applications to successfully create a proof-of-concept educational, shared data internet-of-things data collection and analysis platform, in this case using accurate air quality measurements collected by our Air Quality Egg. Our internet-enabled data collection platform allows students to conduct interesting scientific experiments based on real local scientific data. It can be integrated with existing science curriculum and educational standards. Our innovation supports environmental science education by encouraging students to directly engage in scientific inquiry, and to obtain hands-on experience in collecting and analyzing data from the real world. It encourages engagement in coordinated, collaborative experiments (such as citizen science projects) between classes, schools and diverse geographic regions, that would otherwise be too large in scale and/or geographic spread to implement. This capability opens up a realm of interesting questions and experimental design possibilities with the potential to enrich student’s educational experiences.

During this period, we conducted the following major development activities, addressing any problems that arose:

  • Mobile application (Android, downloadable from the Play Store). We encourage the Readers of this report to install the app on their own phones in order to experience it directly – it does not require an Air Quality Egg to function, because data are open.
  • Website portal. This portal builds on and extends the capabilities of the mobile application.
  • Back-end infrastructure. Application Program Interfaces (APIs) and Databases have been designed to ingest sensor data, and interact with the mobile application and website portal.

This project was designed to address the primary pain point for experiential learning of environmental science: It is nearly impossible to conduct interesting experiments on a limited local basis. The ability to collaborate regionally or globally will enable students to engage in a meaningful exploration the impact of events (anthropomorphic or natural) effect air quality. This project fulfills the federal government and leading-edge STEM educators’ requests that both secondary and postsecondary institutions to teach science in a way engages students with real-world problems. Teaching in this way allows students to harness their own creativity while providing them with experiences that increase the likeliness of these students pursuing both continued STEM education and careers. Studies have shown that this pedagogy is especially effective for encouraging young women to pursue STEM education and careers. This is particularly important as both minorities and women are highly underrepresented in STEM educational programs and career paths. Therefore, to increase the chances of their students pursuing such careers, STEM teachers in high schools and colleges look for novel ways to engage their students with meaningful scientific experiments.
